G.L. c. 215, \u00a7 3.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 215, § 3, and G.L. c. 208, §§ 28 and 31, as the prior custody order was issued by this Court and both parties and the minor child continue to reside in the Commonwealth of Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7\u00a7 28 and 31.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 215, § 3, and G.L. c. 208, §§ 28 and 31, as the prior custody order was issued by this Court and both parties and the minor child continue to reside in the Commonwealth of Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, an existing custody or parenting time order may be modified where (1) a material and substantial change in circumstances has occurred since the entry of the prior judgment, and (2) modification is in the best interests of the child.

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, an existing custody or parenting time order may be modified where (1) a material and substantial change in circumstances has occurred since the entry of the prior judgment, and (2) modification is in the best interests of the child.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31.proposition: The paramount consideration in any custody or parenting time determination is the best interests of the child.

G.L. c. 215, \u00a7 6.proposition: The Court also has broad equitable power to modify custody and parenting orders to protect the child from unnecessary physical or emotional risk and to ensure arrangements are realistically compatible with each parent’s health and abilities.

*Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas*, 395.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, an existing custody or parenting time order may be modified where (1) a material and substantial change in circumstances has occurred since the entry of the prior judgment, and (2) modification is in the best interests of the child.
*Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas*, 395.support_reasoning: The case is a removal/custody allocation decision at the time of divorce, not a post‑judgment modification case. The opinion does not articulate or apply a ‘material and substantial change in circumstances’ standard for modifying an existing custody or parenting time order; instead, it applies the best‑interests and ‘real advantage’ standards under G.L. c. 208, § 30 in the initial divorce judgment. Therefore it does not support the specific two‑prong modification rule described in the proposition.
*Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas*, 395.relevant_excerpt: “The Massachusetts removal statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30 (1984 ed.), provides that ‘[a] minor child of divorced parents who is a native of . . . this commonwealth . . . shall not ... be removed out of this commonwealth ... unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.’ The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child (Rubin v. Rubin, 370 Mass. 857 [1976]; Hale v. Hale, supra at 815), and thus the central question in this case is how these ‘best interests’ are to be determined.”

*Schuler v. Schuler*, 382 Mass. 366 (198.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, an existing custody or parenting time order may be modified where (1) a material and substantial change in circumstances has occurred since the entry of the prior judgment, and (2) modification is in the best interests of the child.
*Schuler v. Schuler*, 382 Mass. 366 (198.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses modification standards for alimony and child support, not custody or parenting time. It states that to modify support the petitioner must show a material change in circumstances, and that child support may be modified as the circumstances of the parents and the benefit of the children may require, but it does not articulate or apply a two-part test for modifying custody/parenting time orders. Therefore, it is not proper authority for the specific custody/parenting time proposition stated.
*Schuler v. Schuler*, 382 Mass. 366 (198.relevant_excerpt: “To be successful in an action to modify a judgment for alimony or child support, the petitioner must demonstrate a material change of circumstances since the entry of the earlier judgment. Robbins v. Robbins, 343 Mass. 247, 249 (1961). Hinds v. Hinds, 329 Mass. 190, 191-192 (1952). … An order for child support may be modified ‘as the circumstances of the parents and the benefit of the children may require.’ G. L. c. 208, § 28…”

*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834, 843\u2.proposition: The paramount consideration in any custody or parenting time determination is the best interests of the child.
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834, 843\u2.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly discusses the historical development and governing role of the “best interests of the child” standard in custody determinations, citing prior Massachusetts cases that state the best interests of the child are the paramount concern. Although this case also interprets statutory factors, it clearly reaffirms that custody awards must be based on the child’s best interests and that all relevant factors must be weighed in light of that standard. Thus, it supports the proposition that the paramount consideration in custody or parenting time decisions is the child’s best interests.
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834, 843\u2.relevant_excerpt: “In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry of what is ‘best for the child’ is firmly rooted in American history… The ‘best interests’ standard appeared in our case law at least as early as 1865… and has been adhered to ever since. See, e.g., … Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704, 710 (1985) (‘best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern’)….”

*Custody of Zia*, 50 Mass. App. Ct. 237,.proposition: The paramount consideration in any custody or parenting time determination is the best interests of the child.
*Custody of Zia*, 50 Mass. App. Ct. 237,.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly states that custody judgments under G.L. c. 209C are made based on a determination of the child's best interests and then discusses how the judge weighed various factors under that standard. The court frames the entire custody analysis, including whether to prefer the primary caretaker, in terms of what serves the child's best interests, confirming that this is the paramount consideration in custody determinations.
*Custody of Zia*, 50 Mass. App. Ct. 237,.relevant_excerpt: “‘[C]ustody orders and judgments [including those under G. L. c. 209C] are made on the basis of a determination of the best interests of the child . . . .’ R. H. v. B. F., 39 Mass. App. Ct. at 39. See Bak v. Bak, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 608, 616 (1987); Carr v. Carr, 44 Mass. App. Ct. at 925; Freedman v. Freedman, 49 Mass. App. Ct. 519, 522 (2000), and a judge may consider any factors found pertinent to those interests in the circumstances of the dispute.”

*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590, 595.proposition: The paramount consideration in any custody or parenting time determination is the best interests of the child.
*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590, 595.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses custody standards and repeatedly frames the analysis in terms of the child’s welfare (e.g., the need to consider domestic violence because of its impact on the child), which is consistent with the best-interests standard as the governing consideration in custody determinations. However, in the excerpt provided the court does not state in so many words that the ‘paramount consideration’ is the best interests of the child; that principle is applied implicitly rather than expressly articulated as a black-letter rule. Thus it does support the proposition, but somewhat indirectly.
*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590, 595.relevant_excerpt:
The Appeals Court based its remand to the Probate Court on the failure of that court to make findings regarding the evidence that the father had physically abused the mother throughout the relationship and the effect of this abuse on the child. . . . [T]he recommendation in [the Gender Bias Study is] that,

"The legislature and/or appellate courts should make it clear that abuse of any family member affects other family members and must be considered in determining the best interests of the child in connection with any order concerning custody."

*Adoption of Hugo*, 428 Mass. 219, 225\u.proposition: In evaluating the best interests of the child, the Court must consider, among other things, the child’s safety, welfare, and emotional well‑being, the capacity of each parent to meet the child’s needs, and the stability and continuity of the child’s care.
*Adoption of Hugo*, 428 Mass. 219, 225\u.support_reasoning: The decision repeatedly frames the judge’s task under the ‘best interests’ standard as weighing Hugo’s safety, welfare, emotional and developmental needs, and the stability and continuity of his care. The court approves the trial judge’s comparison of each proposed caregiver’s capacity to address Hugo’s special needs and provide a consistent, predictable environment, explicitly recognizing stability as an important factor in a young child’s life. Thus, the case directly supports the proposition about what must be considered in a best‑interests analysis.
*Adoption of Hugo*, 428 Mass. 219, 225\u.relevant_excerpt: “Once the judge concluded that parental unfitness was established, he correctly determined that the central question was whether it was in Hugo’s best interests to remain with his foster mother or to be transferred to the care and custody of his aunt… Stability in the life of a child, especially one as young as Hugo, is important, as the judge himself recognized… [T]he judge had to weigh the benefits of stability, of keeping Hugo in his present home, with moving him to a family where, in his judgment, it is more likely that Hugo will receive the home support, stability, and reinforcement of efforts to address his developmental needs so critical to his future development.”

*Custody of Two Minors*, 396 Mass. 610,.proposition: In evaluating the best interests of the child, the Court must consider, among other things, the child’s safety, welfare, and emotional well‑being, the capacity of each parent to meet the child’s needs, and the stability and continuity of the child’s care.
*Custody of Two Minors*, 396 Mass. 610,.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly frames the judge’s task in terms of the children’s best interests and the parents’ current fitness, and it ties that analysis to factors such as the children’s safety, emotional condition, and need for a stable, continuous home environment. The court affirms that the trial judge must make detailed findings concerning the parents’ ability to care and provide for the children, and it emphasizes the importance of a "stable and safe environment" and a "stable, continuous family environment," which directly corresponds to the proposition’s elements of safety, welfare/emotional well‑being, parental capacity, and stability/continuity of care.
*Custody of Two Minors*, 396 Mass. 610,.relevant_excerpt: In custody proceedings, the rights of the children to a stable and safe environment assume an importance at least equal to the interest of the parents in a fair proceeding. … A decision to remove children permanently from the home of their natural parents must be supported by clear and convincing evidence that the parents are currently unfit to care and provide for their children. … [T]he interest of children [is] best served by a stable, continuous family environment.

*Vilakazi v. Maxie*, 371 Mass. 406, 409\.proposition: The Court also has broad equitable power to modify custody and parenting orders to protect the child from unnecessary physical or emotional risk and to ensure arrangements are realistically compatible with each parent’s health and abilities.
*Vilakazi v. Maxie*, 371 Mass. 406, 409\.support_reasoning: The case affirms that custody and visitation orders rest within the judge’s discretion and must be guided by the child’s welfare, including both present and probable future impacts, and explicitly notes that such custody orders are subject to future modification under the relevant statutes. While the opinion does not extensively discuss parental health or abilities, it clearly recognizes broad equitable authority to structure and later modify custody and visitation to protect the child’s well-being, including protection from emotional and physical harm. Thus it generally supports the proposition, though not every specific phrasing (like health/abilities) is directly addressed.
*Vilakazi v. Maxie*, 371 Mass. 406, 409\.relevant_excerpt: “In providing for the custody of a minor child, while the feelings and the wishes of the parents should not be disregarded, the happiness and the welfare of the child should be the controlling consideration. It is the duty of the judge to consider the welfare of the child in reference not merely to the present, but also to the probable future, and it is a subject peculiarly within the discretion of the judge.” … “As to the circumstances in which orders for the custody of minor children may be subject to future modification by the court see G. L. c. 208, §§ 28 and 30 ….”

*Rosenberg v. Merida*, 428 Mass. 182, 19.proposition: The Court also has broad equitable power to modify custody and parenting orders to protect the child from unnecessary physical or emotional risk and to ensure arrangements are realistically compatible with each parent’s health and abilities.
*Rosenberg v. Merida*, 428 Mass. 182, 19.support_reasoning: The case concerns (1) crediting Social Security disability dependency benefits toward child support, (2) attachment of assets to secure support and college expenses, and (3) the standards and findings necessary to modify legal custody. While it mentions the Probate and Family Court’s broad discretion in fashioning judgments to protect children’s interests, it does not discuss modifying parenting orders based on parents’ health or abilities, nor does it frame that discretion in terms of protecting children from unnecessary physical or emotional risk as described in the proposition. Thus, it is too general and not on point for the specific proposition claimed.
*Rosenberg v. Merida*, 428 Mass. 182, 19.relevant_excerpt: “A Probate and Family Court judge has ‘broad discretion to fashion judgments in divorce proceedings that will best protect the interests and welfare of the parties’ minor children.’ Pare v. Pare, 409 Mass. 292, 298-299 (1991). The exact form of the order (or the decision to enter an order at all) is also within the judge’s broad discretion.”

*Custody of a Minor*, 389 Mass. 755, 766.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, such developments concerning a parent’s health and capacity to provide safe care justify revisiting and modifying custody and parenting time orders.
*Custody of a Minor*, 389 Mass. 755, 766.support_reasoning: The opinion is focused on procedural defects in using a care-and-protection proceeding to resolve a custody dispute, and on the substantive standards for removing a child from a parent. It mentions that custody matters must be expedited because circumstances may change, but it does not discuss revisiting or modifying existing custody or parenting time orders in response to developments in a parent’s health or caregiving capacity. The cited pages articulate standards for initial removal and parental unfitness, not for later modification based on changed parental health circumstances.
*Custody of a Minor*, 389 Mass. 755, 766.relevant_excerpt: “Unless proceedings involving the custody of a minor are expedited, they fail to accomplish their purpose. Circumstances may change rapidly, and the harm sought to be avoided may worsen with the passage of time. Here, the child was nine years old when the petition was filed. She is now twelve years old. Prompt resolution of custody issues is essential.”

*Care & Protection of Lillian*, 445 Mass.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, the Court is not required to wait until a child experiences actual harm before modifying an order; a substantial risk to the child’s safety or emotional well‑being is sufficient to warrant modification.
*Care & Protection of Lillian*, 445 Mass.support_reasoning: The court explicitly states that a Juvenile Court “need not wait” until a child is already maltreated before acting in a care and protection matter. It approves proceeding based on allegations that, if true, show the children may be without necessary and proper care, emphasizing protection from risk of abuse or neglect rather than requiring proof of actual, realized harm. This aligns with the proposition that a substantial risk to the child’s safety or emotional well‑being is sufficient to warrant modifying custody arrangements.
*Care & Protection of Lillian*, 445 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “We conclude that if true, these allegations (and the reasonable inferences drawn therefrom) would implicate at least whether the younger children were ‘without necessary and proper physical . . . care’ pursuant to § 24. In making a decision concerning the removal of the children, a ‘court need not wait until it is presented with a maltreated child before it decides the necessity of “care and protection.”’ Custody of a Minor (No. 1), 377 Mass. 876, 882-883 (1979).”

*Adoption of Carla*, 416 Mass. 510, 517\.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, the Court is not required to wait until a child experiences actual harm before modifying an order; a substantial risk to the child’s safety or emotional well‑being is sufficient to warrant modification.
*Adoption of Carla*, 416 Mass. 510, 517\.support_reasoning: The opinion in Adoption of Carla is focused on evidentiary rulings and whether there was clear and convincing evidence of current parental unfitness to support a petition to dispense with consent to adoption. It does not discuss standards for modifying prior custody or visitation orders, nor does it articulate any rule that a court need not wait for actual harm and may act on a substantial risk of harm. The claimed Massachusetts law principle about modification based on substantial risk does not appear in this decision’s holding or reasoning.
*Adoption of Carla*, 416 Mass. 510, 517\.relevant_excerpt: “In a G. L. c. 210, § 3, proceeding, a judge must find by clear and convincing evidence that a parent is presently unfit to provide for the welfare and best interests of the child in order to grant the petition… After reviewing the evidence and testimony properly before the judge, we conclude that the judge’s conclusions were supported by clear and convincing evidence and were not clearly erroneous.”
